thread.title: The Best New Mysteries

author: Tom Nolan
title: The Best New Mysteries
text: ‘It’s one of the first rules of magic,” says master illusionist Max Mephisto, a chief protagonist in English writer Elly Griffith’s clever, immensely likeable series debut, “The Zig Zag Girl” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 328 pages, $25), “people see what they want to see.” But you’d have to pretty twisted to wish to view what police discover in the left-luggage section of the railway station in the seaside resort of Brighton in late 1950. There they find a woman’s dismembered legs and torso stuffed inside plain black cases, “the kind that house the less interesting orchestral instruments, a French horn, maybe, or a...
